byline.original: By STEVEN ERLANGER and STEPHEN CASTLE

abstract: Britain's Labour Party is riven over question of intervention against Islamic State in Syria; new leader Jeremy Corbyn's opposition to use of military force is popular with party's grass roots, but contrasts sharply with position of its members of parliament and shadow ministers.
lead_paragraph: A coming vote on whether to support the government’s call for airstrikes against the Islamic State in Syria has laid bare the conflict over foreign policy in Jeremy Corbyn’s Labour Party.

headline.main: Syria Question Exposes Bitter Divide in Britain’s Labour Party
headline.print_headline: Syria Debate Exposes a Bitter Rift in Britain’s Labour Party

snippet: A coming vote on whether to support the government’s call for airstrikes against the Islamic State in Syria has laid bare the conflict over foreign policy in Jeremy Corbyn’s Labour Party.

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
